content:
I am a senior undergraduate at IIT Kanpur majoring in Electrical Engineering with a second major in Computer Science. I am interested in solving problems in Machine Learning, Convex Optimization and Computer Vision.
Presently, I am a research assistant at IITK's SPiN Lab, working with Prof. Ketan Rajawat on problems in online convex optimization. We are currently working on my first paper, which we plan to submit soon.
Prior to this, I have worked with Prof. Satyadev Nandakumar, where we focused on developing a principled intuition behind Hamiltonian Monte Carlo and its optimal implementations. I also had the chance to work with Prof. Vinay P. Namboodiri and Ravindra Yadav on video generation using VAEs. In the summer of 2018, I was an intern in the Isolation Product Line of Texas Instruments, India, working with Koteshwar Rao to improve upon the design of TI's digital isolators.

content: Location This project started as part of my summer research internship at IITK's SPiN Lab under Prof. Ketan Rajawat. Since then, we have designed two novel algorithms and are currently working on suitable experiments and writing the paper, which we hope to finish and submit soon.
summary: Designed a No constraint violation algorithm with theoretical guarantees for sublinear dynamic regret for the Online Convex Optimization (OCO) problem after performing a thorough literature survey on the existing work in OCO. Extended the algorithm to the distributed setting by imposing an extended Slater’s condition to establish strong duality for feasible optimization.
title: Online Constrained Convex Optimization using Mirror Descent

content: Location This was my second undergraduate research project under Prof. Vinay P. Namboodiri, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kanpur, which I took up after completing his course CS 783 : Visual Recognition in the Spring ‘19 term.
summary: Performed a literature survey on generative models and video generation using GANs/VAEs. Designed and implemented a video generation model in PyTorch, based on the MVAE model by Wu and Goodman, 2018. Proposed improvement of the model by replacing the MSE error with a GAN discriminator, and training the model from end-to-end.
title: Video Generation using Multimodal VAE

content: Location This was my first undergraduate research project under Prof. Satyadev Nandakumar, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kanpur, which I took up concurrently with his course CS 687 : Algorithmic Information Theory in the Spring ‘19 term.
summary: Provided a comprehensive conceptual account of the theoretical foundations of Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. Focused on developing a principled intuition behind the HMC method and its optimal implementations. The discussion also included some of the popular extensions to Hamiltonian Monte Carlo and how they address specific problems.
title: Conceptual motivation of MCMC using Hamiltonian Dynamics

content: Location This was a research project at EPFL's MLO Lab, mentored by Prof. Martin Jaggi and Prof. Aymeric Dieulevieut during my semester exchange at EPFL in the fall of 2018.
summary: Developed theoretical convergence guarantees for different strategies to restart SGD algorithms in the convex setting. Worked with and compared different existing SGD algorithms including the new SGD1/2. Implemented variations of the same to see if any improvements are obtained.
title: Restart strategies for SGD

content: Location This project was done as part of the course EE604 : Image Processing in the Spring ‘18 term at IIT Kanpur under Prof. K S Venkatesh, Department of Electrical Engineering, IIT Kanpur.
summary: Created caricatures of the face from the given image of face of an individual. Caricature is a comical representation highlighting of the distinct features of the face of that individual.
title: Creating face caricatures

content: Location This project was done as part of the course CS771: Machine Learning Techniques, in the Fall ‘17 term at IIT Kanpur under Prof. Purushottam Kar, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kanpur.
summary: Used Deep Reinforcement learning to learn models which can achieve super-human performance on the popular game ‘Flappy bird’. Used DQN to accept raw pixels as input from a pygame simulation, and took actions based on the output which estimated future rewards (Q-values for actions possible). Designed and implemented a policy-gradient version separately, and compared the performance of the two methods.
title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Atari Games

content: Location This project was done as part of the course CS698X: Topics in Probabilistic Machine Learning and Inference, in the Spring ‘18 term at IIT Kanpur under Prof. Piyush Rai, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kanpur.
summary: Studied recent attempts to reach a middle-ground (between performance and simplicity) for large scale data, using small variance asymptotics, to get a non parametric model which is scalable. Implemented the existing approaches to tackle the problem like Dirichlet Process Mixture Models, and extended this algorithm to a hierarchical structure using Hierarchical Dirichlet process. Generalized the clustering algorithm to use Bregman divergences. Used the models to perform clustering on the iris dataset, among others, while evaluating the performance using standard (NMI) and custom validation techniques.
title: Small variance asymptotics for non-parametric Bayesian clustering
